pullRequest.body:
Strictly speaking, something like this was available as `LinearMap.proj`, but actually using it in practice is awkward as unification struggles (see line 1227 in this PR). 

I'm happy to take name suggestions, as well as ideas for other generalities.

---
<!-- The text above the `---` will become the commit message when your
PR is merged. Please leave a blank newline before the `---`, otherwise
GitHub will format the text above it as a title.

For details on the "pull request lifecycle" in mathlib, please see:
https://leanprover-community.github.io/contribute/index.html

In particular, note that most reviewers will only notice your PR
if it passes the continuous integration checks.
Please ask for help on https://leanprover.zulipchat.com if needed.

To indicate co-authors, include lines at the bottom of the commit message
(that is, before the `---`) using the following format:

Co-authored-by: Author Name <author@email.com>

If you are moving or deleting declarations, please include these lines at the bottom of the commit message
(that is, before the `---`) using the following format:

Moves:
- Vector.* -> Mathlib.Vector.*
- ...

Deletions:
- Nat.bit1_add_bit1
- ...

Any other comments you want to keep out of the PR commit should go
below the `---`, and placed outside this HTML comment, or else they
will be invisible to reviewers.

If this PR depends on other PRs, please list them below this comment,
using the following format:
- [ ] depends on: #abc [optional extra text]
- [ ] depends on: #xyz [optional extra text]

-->

| File | Base Count | Head Count | Change |
| --- | --- | --- | --- |
| Mathlib.Data.Matrix.Basic | 806 | 808 | +2 (+0.25%) |


<details><summary>Import changes for all files</summary>

|Files|Import difference|
|-|-|
|<details><summary>13 files</summary> `Mathlib.Data.Matrix.Auto` `Mathlib.Combinatorics.SimpleGraph.StronglyRegular` `Mathlib.Data.Matrix.Basis` `Mathlib.GroupTheory.Coxeter.Matrix` `Mathlib.GroupTheory.Coxeter.Basic` `Mathlib.Data.Matrix.Reflection` `Mathlib.LinearAlgebra.Matrix.Trace` `Mathlib.GroupTheory.Coxeter.Inversion` `Mathlib.GroupTheory.Coxeter.Length` `Mathlib.Data.Matrix.Hadamard` `Mathlib.Combinatorics.Optimization.ValuedCSP` `Mathlib.Data.Matrix.Notation` `Mathlib.Combinatorics.SimpleGraph.AdjMatrix`</details>|1|
|<details><summary>14 files</summary> `Mathlib.Data.Matrix.Invertible` `Mathlib.Data.Matrix.Composition` `Mathlib.Data.Matrix.Basic` `Mathlib.Data.Matrix.PEquiv` `Mathlib.Data.Matrix.CharP` `Mathlib.Data.Matrix.Block` `Mathlib.CategoryTheory.Preadditive.Mat` `Mathlib.Topology.UniformSpace.Matrix` `Mathlib.LinearAlgebra.Matrix.Symmetric` `Mathlib.Data.Matrix.RowCol` `Mathlib.Data.Matrix.DualNumber` `Mathlib.Combinatorics.SimpleGraph.IncMatrix` `Mathlib.LinearAlgebra.Matrix.Circulant` `Mathlib.LinearAlgebra.Matrix.Orthogonal`</details>|2|

</details>

</details>

---

#### Declarations diff

</summary>

`+ entryAddMonoidHom_toAddHom`
`+ entryLinearMap`

`+ entryLinearMap_toAddHom`
`+ entryLinearMap_toAddMonoidHom`
`+ evalAddMonoidHom_comp_diagAddMonoidHom`
`+ mapMatrix_toLinearMap`
`+ ofAddEquiv`
`+ ofLinearEquiv`
`+ proj_comp_diagLinearMap`
`++ entryLinearMap_comp_mapMatrix`
<details>
  <summary>You can run this locally as follows</summary>


```bash
## summary with just the declaration names:
./scripts/declarations_diff.sh <optional_commit>

## more verbose report:
./scripts/declarations_diff.sh long <optional_commit>
```
</details>

The doc-module for `script/declarations_diff.sh` contains some details about this script.

</details>
(Oops, putting this back to WIP because I realised I want to add a bit more to it!)

I'm content with this now. @eric-wieser I'll leave it to you.

bors d=eric-wieser

:v: eric-wieser can now approve this pull request. To approve and merge a pull request, simply reply with `bors r+`. More detailed instructions are available [here](https://bors.tech/documentation/getting-started/#reviewing-pull-requests).

:v: b-mehta can now approve this pull request. To approve and merge a pull request, simply reply with `bors r+`. More detailed instructions are available [here](https://bors.tech/documentation/getting-started/#reviewing-pull-requests).
bors merge

Pull request successfully merged into master.

Build succeeded:
  * [Build](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/11490160201/job/31980346819)
  * [Lint style](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/11490160201/job/31980347200)
Maybe `Matrix.elemAddMonoidHom` and `Matrix.elimLinearMap` as the names?
I don't mind `elem`, but the pattern for `mapMatrix` is to prefix with the structure, eg `LinearMap.mapMatrix` and `AddMonoidHom.mapMatrix`, so I'd prefer to stick with that.
Those are named that way for `f.mapMatrix M` dot notation, since `M.mapRingHom f` doesn't work with morphisms and is morally the wrong order for function application. I don't think that applies here.
Either way, I think this should include the word `Matrix` in the name somewhere, namespace or otherwise.
Ah fair point - I didn't consider the dot notation. Will amend.
done

I would be tempted to name this like so, and similarly throughout. Do you prefer it?
```suggestion
/-- Extracting entries from a matrix as an additive homomorphism.  -/
@[simps]
def entryAddHom (i : m) (j : n) : AddHom (Matrix m n )  where
```
I'm happy with `entry` or `elem`, but `elem` was @eric-wieser's suggestion, so let's ask him too. Actually, `elem` already has a different connotation for arrays, so `entry` does seem better.
I'm happy with either.
changed.

I understand why you named it this way, but `proj` doesn't appear on the RHS.
```suggestion
lemma elemAddHom_eq_piEval {i : m} {j : n} :
    elemAddHom  i j = (Pi.evalAddHom _ j).comp (Pi.evalAddHom _ i : AddHom _ (n  )) :=
```
Actually my name was for a worse reason than you guessed: it's because of a lazy copy-paste. Thanks for catching this!
This naming is fine also (i.e., not specifying the RHS), but let's be consistent throughout for parallelism.
Is there a reason to have these as opposed to the versions utilizing the hom class coercions?
Oops, the first one gets elaborated to the hom class coercions but the second doesn't, that's a mistake on my part. Will amend.
Oh, actually they are all utilizing the hom class coercions already. Could you clarify what you meant then?
I changed the spelling for clarity.
I don't understand how these could be the hom class coercions, because they are both structure projections? What makes you say that `LinearMap.toAddMonoidHom` is a hom class coercion?
Of course the updated spelling makes it moot, but I just want this point clarified for both our sakes.
Same here
Arguably you should launder through `of` here to avoid needing the type ascription.

~~I'm not quite sure I follow - `of` is for building matrices, but both sides here are maps out of a matrix space. I'm happy to use `of`, but I don't see how it fits here.~~ 
Oops, didn't realise `of` was an equiv. I'm still not sure how to make it fit though, because it doesn't give me a linear map
You could add an `ofLinearEquiv` as a linear version of `of`.
Sounds potentially helpful but a can of worms I'd rather not open here (AddEquiv; LinearEquiv; RingEquiv; AlgebraEquiv...). Would you be happy with a todo instead?
I think it's fine to just add the bundling you need; the simp-normal form would remain `of`

The add monoid hom one end up looking like this
```
lemma entryAddMonoidHom_eq_comp {i : m} {j : n} :
    entryAddMonoidHom  i j =
      ((Pi.evalAddMonoidHom _ j).comp (Pi.evalAddMonoidHom _ i)).comp
        (AddMonoidHomClass.toAddMonoidHom ofAddEquiv.symm) :=
  rfl
```
Are you sure this is a good idea?

> You could add an `ofLinearEquiv` as a linear version of `of`.

I needed this anyway in #18097.

> Are you sure this is a good idea?

Yes, because it means if you apply this lemma then use `simp`, the `of` reappears where it should.
Okay, I added it in the most recent commit (from two weeks ago)

Can you add the `symm` lemmas too?

bors d+

pullRequest.title: [Merged by Bors] - feat(Matrix): extracting entries as a linear map
